awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Security of Smart Things
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding renews a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the Florida International University.  This REU Site will host a diverse group of students from universities across the nation who will spend their summer working on research related to the security and privacy of smart things.  Smart devices are found in our homes and daily environment in many places such as appliances, phones, cameras, and cars as well as many other common applications.  Since these devices can communicate and process data, they are vulnerable to various networking and software attacks such as malware, unauthorized access, impersonation, data modification, and denial of service.  The research is led by an experienced faculty team that plans to offer a balance of theory, applications, and practical skills as well as mentoring and professional development opportunities for the students.  The students will learn how to design, implement, and assess research projects in areas that are becoming crucial for the safety and privacy of all citizens. The site will focus on recruiting under-represented minorities, particularly drawing on the surrounding universities with large Hispanic populations. This site is co-funded by the CISE Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) Program.

The project will introduce practical innovations and mechanisms for maintaining the privacy and security of smart devices such as wearable technologies, appliances, and mobile devices as well as smart homes and cities that deploy these devices.  This will be achieved through the use of state-of-the art facilities run by faculty members with significant expertise in the security of smart things.  The goals of the project include providing a quality research experience for undergraduates, increasing participation of female and under-represented minorities in computing fields, preparing students to pursue graduate studies in cyber security fields, and building a community of security of smart things researchers.  By the end of the program, the students should acquire skills that will lead to rewarding professional careers that are vital for preserving our national security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site at Florida International University in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering focused on security and privacy aspects of smart things which could be deployed in our daily lives. The site trained 23 students in 3 years and involved them in various practical projects under the supervision of 5 faculty mentors. The following summarizes the coutcomes and findings: 

- One of the goals of the REU Site was to provide opportunities to minority students so that they can pursue careers in cybersecurity. To this end, 8 females (35%), 15 minorities (70%) and  15 (65%) students from non-traditional schools were supported. 

- The students contributed to critical projects that relate to cybersecurity of smart things. 5 of the students were able to publish their work in peer-reviewed technical venues while some of them are still working on their papers. In addition, one of the students published his REU work in a top-ranked cybersecurity conference while another helped FIU researchers file a joint patent with a local startup in Miami. These achievements are exceptional for students at the undergradaute level. 

- The REU program also made a major impact on the career paths of these participating students. So far among graduates, 5 of them joined/completed the graduate schools in various universities while many of them got prestigious jobs in STEM related companies and government institutions. 

- The REU program featured various speakers on topics that relate to professional development. This contributed to the skills of the participating students in terms of paper writing, technical presentations, poster design, and literature research. 

- There were various technical innovations that came out from this program. Some selected brief results are as follows:

* A highly cost effective and reliable IoT data forensics storage mechanism was proposed (and patented) by exploiting multiple inexpensive blockchain networks as a temporary storage before the data is committed to a public blockchain.

* A special blockchain-based forensic framework is proposed to verify the integrity and authenticity of videos captured by wireless-based IoT devices such as drones or body cameras. 

- A highly accurate machine learning based mechanism was proposed for detecting incorrect data that are injected into the data bus of self driving vehicles. 

- A method for improving consensus time of proof-of-work blockchains within a wireless mesh network that utilizes WiFi was proposed using network coding techniques.
